name: cystophora-cristata
definition: The hooded seal  is a large phocid found only in the central and western North Atlantic, ranging from Svalbard in the east to the  Gulf of St. Lawrence.
description:
The hooded seal is a large member of the Phocid family.

It is silver-gray with irregular black spots over most of its body and a face which is often completely black.

Its most distinctive feature is the male’s prominent nasal ornament, which is a loose, wrinkled sac hanging in the front of the nose.

During the time of mating, males will inflate this sac as a form of display to females, as well as to other males.

It then becomes a tight, bi-lobed hood and covers the face and top of the head.

Hooded seals migrate within a range that includes a large area of the North Atlantic.

Their migration usually follows the movement of pack-ice.

The four main areas for pupping include the east of Greenland, the Gulf of St Lawrence, Newfoundland and the Davis Strait.

This species is normally not too far from pack-ice, but also spends much time in the open sea.

Hooded seals are carnivores, more precisely piscivores and molluscivores.

They eat a range of marine prey, particularly fish, including redfish, herring, flounder and polar cod.

Hooded seals also eat octopus and shrimp.

Natural predators of hooded seals include sharks, polar bears, and killer whales.

Polar bears mainly feed on harp and bearded seals but will hunt hooded seals when they are breeding on ice and are more visible, vulnerable targets.

This species is polygynous.

April to June is the typical period for mating, and gestation lasts 240 to 250 days.

A single young is born.

At birth young are precocial, able to move around and swim with ease.

Being independent at weaning, which is after 5 to 12 days, they are left to look after themselves.

The hooded seal is diurnal and mostly solitary, except when breeding and molting, at which time it fasts.

It does not compete for social hierarchy or territory.

These animals can make vocalizations like roars that are easily heard on land.

Their most important means of communication is made by their hood and nasal septum.

Hooded seals can produce pulses that range from 6 to 500 Hz, which are often heard both in the water and on land.

They move their inflated hood and septum up and down, creating pings and whooshes.

Hooded seal population is approximately 340,000 individuals.

Currently this species is classified as vulnerable on the IUCN Red List.

facts.name: Group is known as pod
facts.value: Group of hooded seals is known as pod, harem, colony, flock, herd and rockery.

facts.name: Males are larger than females
facts.value: Males of hooded seals are larger than females. They can reach 2.7 to 3 meters in length and weigh of 400 kilograms. Females are usually 1.8 to 2.1 meters long, with 320 kilograms of weight.

facts.name: Hooded seals have long lifespan
facts.value: Hooded seals have long lifespan. They can survive between 30 and 35 years in the wild. Captive hooded seals are prone to tuberculosis and cranial infections.

facts.name: Spends parts of its life on ice blocks
facts.value: Hooded seal spends parts of its life on ice blocks that are floating in the ocean, and other part in the water, where it is searching for food.

facts.name: Pregnancy lasts 11 months
facts.value: Pregnancy in hooded seals lasts 11 months and it ends with a single baby. Hooded seals have the shortest period of lactation (breast-feeding) of all mammals. Babies suckle only 4 to 5 days.

facts.name: Hooded seal is solitary animal
facts.value: Hooded seal is solitary animal. It gathers with other hooded seals only during mating season.

facts.name: Inflate the hood when they are threatened
facts.value: Males inflate their hood when they are threatened or excited. Hood plays important role during mating season. Males with larger hoods have better chances to mate.

facts.name: Hooded seal predators
facts.value: Main predators of hooded seal are killer whales, sharks and polar bears.

facts.name: Hooded seals have large flippers
facts.value: Hooded seals have large flippers, used for swimming. Flippers end with sharp claws.

facts.name: Mother's milk is rich in fat
facts.value: Although suckling lasts only couple of days, mother's milk is rich in fat and babies can double their size immediately. After this period, young hooded seals can start eating like adult animals. Hooded seals reach sexual maturity at the age of five years.

facts.name: Hooded seal is carnivore
facts.value: Hooded seal is carnivore (meat-eater). It usually eats fish such as redfish, herring, cod, and capelin. Besides fish, hooded seal hunts octopuses, shrimps, squids and mussels.

facts.name: Body is covered with thick fur
facts.value: Body of hooded seal is covered with thick fur that is usually grey or blue-gray in color. Fur is covered with irregular spots that can be light or dark in color.

facts.name: Hood looks like a red balloon
facts.value: The most prominent feature on the body of hooded seal is a hood that looks like a large red balloon when inflated.

facts.name: Hood is two times bigger than the football
facts.value: Average hood is two times bigger than the football, with a volume of around 6.3 liters. When inflated, hood doubles the size of the seal's head.

facts.name: Hood is an enlargement of the nasal cavity
facts.value: Hood is an enlargement of the nasal cavity. It can be seen only in males. Hood starts to develop at the age of 4 years, and it becomes fully developed at age of 12 years.

related.definition: The ringed seal , also known as the jar seal, as netsik or nattiq by the Inuit, is an earless seal inhabiting the Arctic and sub-Arctic regions.
The leopard seal is the second largest species of seal in the Antarctic.
The harbor  seal is a true seal found along temperate and Arctic marine coastlines of the Northern Hemisphere.
The southern elephant seal  is one of the two species of elephant seals.
The Mediterranean monk seal  is a monk seal belonging to the family Phocidae.
The crabeater seal s a true seal with a circumpolar distribution around the coast of Antarctica.
